Query1.title: Scientists have an explanation why there is an increase of shark ...
Query1.snippet: Jul 26, 2022 ... Beaches have closed as surfers, lifeguards and swimmers alike suffer bites from curious sharks in search of food.

content.content:
Underwater creatures that have been dominating the oceans since before the dinosaurs roamed the earth have been causing quite a stir this summer with what seems like an .
An uptick in human-shark interactions has been occurring on the shores of the Atlantic Ocean off Long Island, New York -- so much so that beaches have closed as surfers, lifeguards and swimmers alike suffer bites from curious sharks in search of food.
At least five shark attacks have occurred in the Northeast since June 30. Further south in Keaton Beach, Florida, a teen  after punching the shark in the nose. On Wednesday, a dead great white shark washed ashore on Kismet Beach on Fire Island, a barrier island in New York.
The increase in activity may have those seeking relief from the  wondering whether it is safe to venture to the beaches this summer.
!
A surfer arrives at Rockaway Beach, July 19, 2022, in Queens, New York. A number of factors, including warming ocean temperatures, are contributing to an expected proliferation of sharks along the New York coastline this summer.
Frank Franklin Ii/AP
Here is why there seem to be more shark attacks on the East Coast this summer, according to experts:
### Global warming may play a factor
While there is no data to suggest climate change is responsible for pushing sharks closer to the shore, there may be other factors in which warmer waters cause sharks to venture near human beings, James Sulikowski, marine biologist and founder of Arizona State University’s Sulikowski Shark and Fish Conservation Lab, told ABC News.
Much of marine life existing beneath the surface are tied to...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: ABC News is a well-established news organization with a long history of journalism. It follows ethical guidelines for reporting and fact-checking. While it is generally reliable, it may occasionally be criticized for bias or sensationalism, but it still provides valuable news coverage and analysis.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses an increase in shark-human interactions, indicating that sharks might be looking for food, which strongly relates to their presence in the surfer context. It provides a clear explanation as to why a shark might be nearby, indicating a notable relevance to the situation described in the video.

Query1.title: The real reasons why sharks attack humans
Query1.snippet: Aug 9, 2019 ... But then something took hold of her leg. The water around Mighall exploded as a five-metre-long great white shark latched onto her ...

content.content:
Shark attacks are still relatively rare occurrences even though humans should be easy prey compared to fast-moving fish and seals. But when they do happen, they can be devastating. So, why do sharks attack people?
The crystal-clear water beneath 13-year-old Hannah Mighall darkened for a moment. She was sitting astride her surfboard, enjoying the warmth of the sun as she and her cousin waited for the next wave in Tasmania’s idyllic Bay of Fires. Behind them the brilliant-white sandy beach was largely deserted and the surfing had been good so far.
The sudden shadow below made Mighall instinctively lift her feet – balls of kelp often broke off nearby rocks and drifted in the surf. “They are really slimy so I hated touching them,” she says.
But then something took hold of her leg.
“It didn’t hurt at first, it was like something gently grabbed hold of me and then I was in the water,” says Mighall.
To those who witnessed what happened, however, it was anything but gentle. The water around Mighall exploded as a five-metre-long great white shark latched onto her right leg, lifted her off the surfboard and shook her in the air before disappearing underwater.
“It took a few seconds for me to realise it was a shark,” she says. “When I popped back up from the water I was lying on my back but my leg was in its mouth. All I could see was my black wetsuit leg, its teeth, pink gums, teeth and the dark bit under its nose where it meets white. I thought I was having a nightmare and kept trying to blink my eyes open.”
Mighall’s cousin, 33-year-old Syb Mundy, who had been sitting on his own board just a few metres from her, raced over and began punching the shark in the side of its head. The shark pulled away from him and as it went underwater it let go of Mighall, lunging instead for her surfboard that was still attached by a rope to her leg.
You might also be interested in:
• The man who ran out of air
• Could your swimwear attract sharks?
• The secret nursery of hammerhead sharks
With the board in its mouth, the shark pulled Mighall underwater for a second time. Moments later she popped back up to the surface with her damaged board. The animal had bitten clean through the fibreg...[Content truncated]

It has a strong reputation for accuracy and thorough fact-checking, making it a good source for reliable information on various topics, including marine life and safety.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This article explores the reasons why sharks may attack humans, highlighting patterns of behavior when sharks mistake surfers for prey. This provides context about why sharks may be present near surfers, thus offering a plausible explanation for their presence in the video. It contributes meaningfully to understanding the dynamics between sharks and surfers, but it doesn’t directly explain the specific case in the video.

Query2.title: Southern California Surfers Better Get Used to Seeing Great White ...
Query2.snippet: Jun 6, 2024 ... And regarding the now standard rationalization provided by various shark researchers and well-meaning ocean conservation advocates that the ...

content.content:
Reading headlines about two “interactions” between great white sharks and Southern California surfers taking place in the same week, at breaks where until very recently shark encounters were absolutely unknown, gives me pause, to say the least. And regarding the now standard rationalization provided by various shark researchers and well-meaning ocean conservation advocates that the increased number of these interactions proves that California has always been teeming with white sharks and these “rare” and sometimes fatal instances of mistaken identity are simply the result of there being more surfers, not more white sharks, has me wanting to respond with complete conviction: “Bullsh-t!” 
Before howling in outrage, follow me here, my hypothesis beginning with a personal, and very pertinent, anecdote. 
It was an irrational fear, we knew, but a dread fear nevertheless; this was 1977, after all, and the release of Steven Spielberg’s blockbuster movie Jaws two years previous was still fresh in everybody’s minds. We thought about great white sharks a lot while surfing along California’s Central Coast, ranging from Pismo Beach up through Big Sur, especially at spots deemed, for various reasons, to be “sharky.”
 Funny thing, though, was that up to this point none of us had ever seen a great white shark, nor knew anyone who had. Our trepidation was fueled purely by the imagination, the peril existing only in the abstract. Until that one day in Cayucos. We were surfing a spot called Toro Creek, me and friends Jeff Chamberlain and Rick Black, settling into a fun, three-to four-foot beachbreak session. The day before, Jeff had reported speaking to a Morro Bay fisherman who claimed to have seen a large shark in the area; probably a basking shark, he said. Big, but harmless. But then...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Inertia is a reputable site focused on surf and outdoor culture, featuring articles that discuss environmental issues, surf culture, and athlete interviews. While the website offers informative content, it is not primarily dedicated to hard news or fact-checking. The Inertia has a good reputation within the surfing community, but readers should be cautious as it may not have the same stringent editorial standards as more traditional news organizations.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses interactions between surfers and great white sharks but centers on the concept of increasing encounters rather than providing a definitive alternative explanation for why a shark might be near surfers. Its critique regarding misconceptions about shark behaviors helps contextualize the video, yet it lacks detailed explanations specifically tied to the video content.

Advertisement

Scientific Reports
volume 8, Article number: 3676 (2018)
            Cite this article

9411 Accesses
32 Citations
41 Altmetric
Metrics details
An Author Correction to this article was published on 04 July 2018
This article has been updated
Understanding the environmental drivers of interactions between predators and humans is critical for public safety and management purposes. In the marine environment, this issue is exemplified by shark-human interactions. The annual shark bite incidence rate (SBIR) in La Réunion (Indian Ocean) is among the highest in the world (up to 1 event per 24,000 hours of surfing) and has experienced a 23-fold increase over the 2005–2016 period. Since 1988, 86% of shark bite events on surfers involved ocean-users off the leeward coast, where 96% of surfing activities took place. We modeled the SBIR as a function of environmental variables, including benthic substrate, sea temperature and period of day. The SBIR peaked in winter, during the afternoon and dramatically increased on coral substrate since the mid-2000s. Seasonal patterns of increasing SBIR followed similar fluctuations of large coastal shark occurrences (particularly the bull shark Carcharhinus leucas), consistent with the hypothesis that higher shark presence may result in an increasing likelihood of shark bite events. Potential contributing factors and adaptation of ocean-users to the increasing shark bite hazard are discussed. This interdisciplinary research contributes to a better understanding of shark-human interactions. The modeling method is relevant for wildlife hazard management in general.
Human–wildlife conflicts...[Content truncated]

The articles published are peer-reviewed and well-researched, contributing to its high reliability and credibility. As a resource for scientific literature, it supports truthfulness and depth in coverage, making it an excellent source for assessing claims like those concerning marine behavior or ecology related to sharks.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence evaluates various factors affecting shark-human interactions and suggests environmental influences, which can explain the increased likelihood of sharks being present alongside surfers. Its focus on environmental drivers and shark behaviors, detailing human activity influencing these patterns, is very relevant for understanding plausible explanations for the presence of sharks in the video.

QA.Question: What alternative explanations exist for the presence of a shark alongside surfers in the video?
QA.Answer:
There are several alternative explanations for the presence of a shark alongside surfers in the video:

1. **Natural Shark Behavior**: Sharks, including great whites, often inhabit waters near popular surfing areas due to the availability of prey. It is not uncommon for sharks to be present in regions frequented by surfers, as they may be attracted to schools of fish or other marine life, rather than being directly interested in surfers themselves. This phenomenon suggests that the presence of sharks near surfers may be a result of natural predatory behaviors rather than targeted interactions with humans.

2. **Increased Shark Populations and Sightings**: Research indicates that shark populations may be increasing in certain areas, leading to more frequent sightings of these creatures. For example, data has shown that specific regions experience higher rates of shark attacks correlating with the abundance of sharks in those waters, which may result in more surfers encountering sharks as sharks expand their range without necessarily targeting surfers specifically.

3. **Misinterpretation of Shark Behavior**: Often, the mere sighting of a shark, such as a dorsal fin, can be sensationalized in media. In many instances, these creatures are simply swimming by and not exhibiting aggressive behavior. Understanding that shark-human interactions are often overstated can clarify the nature of these occurrences: sharks do not always pose a threat to surfers and may be largely indifferent to their presence.

4. **Changes in Human Activity**: As more people engage in water sports like surfing, the number of encounters between humans and sharks naturally increases. This is supported by the idea that as the number of surfers rises, the likelihood of an encounter increases, not necessarily indicating an increase in shark aggression or intent.

Based on the analysis of the evidence and the reasoning process, I would evaluate my confidence in this explanation to be **90%**. This evaluation is based on the consistencies found across various studies regarding shark behavior and interactions with humans, emphasizing the need to contextualize such encounters rather than interpret them as direct threats or intentional actions by the sharks.
